Description: Teardrop weight carved from grey hard stone, likely basalt; ovoid shape with flat base, a wider rounded end and the other flat; smoothed surface; complete.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Oriental Institute, University of Chicago. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Teardrop, or ovoid, weights are rare in Naukratis as in Egypt in general (Petrie 1886, pl. XXIII; Cour-Marty 1990, 26, fig. 8, fig. 13 and fig. 26). They appear to be more numerous in the New Kingdom than in later periods (Cour-Marty 1990, fig. 26). These weights are associated either to the Egyptian standard deben-kedet which weights around 9-9,5 g, or to another standard which unit weights around 8g, like this example. The latter standard could correspond to the Near Eastern shekel or the Greek stater (Cour-Marty 1990, 24-25, fig. 22-24; Kroll 2003, 317; van Alfen 2002, 184, n. 654). With its mass of 7,9 g, this specimen could correspond more specifically to one shekel. Cour-Marty, M.-A. 1989. Les poids dans l’Égypte ancienne, Vols. 1-3 [unpublished thesis, microform], Paris. Cour-Marty, M.-A. 1990, 'Les poids égyptiens, de précieux jalons archéologiques', Cahier de Recherches de l'Institut de Papyrologie et d'Egyptologie de Lille 12, 17-55. Kroll, J. H. 2003. ‘Weights, bullion, currency, coinage’, in N. Ch. Stampolidis and V. Karageorghis (eds), Ploes. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I., 1884–5 (third memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Petrie, W. M. F. 1926, Ancient Weights and Measures Illustrated by the Egyptian Collection in University College, London. van Alfen, P.
